channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Sets Stage for Battle to Control Ukraine’s East
item.description: Moscow is moving helicopters to Ukraine’s eastern border and bringing in soldiers, the Pentagon says. Russian long-range bombers joined the fight against defenders in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recovery workers digging through rubble in Borodianka, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Live Updates: Jerusalem Calms After Israeli-Palestinian Clashes at Holy Site
item.description: Violence broke out at the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, in the morning on the first day of a rare convergence of Ramadan, Easter and Passover.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians and the Israeli police clashing at the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem on Friday.

item.title: A Soviet-Era Air Defense System Arrives in Ukraine From Slovakia
item.description: Encouraged by the United States, Slovakia “donated” a bulky but effective S-300, hoping to challenge Russian domination of the skies in the war next door.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Dobra, Slovakia, where the S-300 antiaircraft system recently provided by the country to Ukraine was loaded on a train to be transferred over the border.

item.title: What Boris Johnson’s Deal With Rwanda Means for U.K. Asylum System
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.K. Border Force cutter Vigilant bringing refugees into Dover last year after picking them up in the English Channel.

item.title: Israeli police clashed with Palestinian stone throwers for hours.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians and the Israeli police clashing at the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem on Friday.

item.title: Faced With a Changed Europe, China Sticks to an Old Script
item.description: Europe was viewed as lacking the power and the will to contest China’s rise. But now, a harder line toward Russia has implications for Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: At a video meeting on April 1 with European officials, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, made clear the country would not distance itself from Russia.

item.title: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
item.description: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Samia Suluhu Hassan of Tanzania this month at Chamwino State House in the capital, Dodoma.

item.title: Families of U.K. Covid Victims React to Boris Johnson Fines
item.description: Those unable to be with dying loved ones find no satisfaction or closure with the penalty Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces for breaking lockdown rules.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak, the chancellor of the Exchequer, in London in 2020. Both were fined for breaching pandemic lockdown laws.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Gives North Korean TV Anchor a Luxury Home
item.description: Ri Chun-hee, who delivers the news with a soaring, bombastic tenor, received a two-story apartment in a riverside complex from the country’s leader, apparently for her loyalty.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and Ri Chun-hee at the new building in Pyongyang this week.

item.title: Former French Colonies in Africa Demand a Reset
item.description: Decades after independence, many African countries are increasingly troubled by the ongoing influence of their former colonial power.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesters in Bamako, the capital of Mali, during a demonstration last year against French influence in the country.

item.title: U.K. Plans to Send Some Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
item.description: Britain says it will fly many refugees thousands of miles to the central African country for processing and resettlement, a significant hardening of migration policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Megan Specia and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Asylum seekers waiting for their claims to be processed protesting last year outside the hotel where they were being housed in London.

item.title: Europe Reluctantly Readies Russian Oil Embargo
item.description: Officials are drafting a phased import ban on Russian oil products, but the measure won’t be floated until after the second round of the French elections at the earliest.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The Leuna oil refinery, which receives Russian oil via the Druzhba pipeline, in Spergau, Germany earlier this week.

item.title: Russia’s Storied Ballet Is Among the Casualties of War
item.description: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The star ballerina Olga Smirnova with Semyon Chudin at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow in 2014.

item.title: Japanese TV Show “Old Enough!” Features Toddlers Running Errands
item.description: “Old Enough!,” a Japanese show that has been on the air for decades, recently came to Netflix. It features toddlers running errands without adult supervision.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Miro, a 2-year-old in Mameda, Japan, runs an errand in the reality TV show “Old Enough!”

item.title: How Russian Disinformation Spreads Beyond Its Borders
item.description: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky and Emily Rhyne
item.media:description: Emily Rhyne/The New York Times

item.title: Shanghai’s Isolation Facilities Have Prompted a Backlash
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Shanghai residents have been sent to quarantine and isolation facilities. One woman described her ordeal.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson

item.title: Quiz Time on the Campaign Trail
item.description: Several “gotcha” questions for candidates, including one that Anthony Albanese got wrong, raise deeper questions about the quality of the nation’s political discourse.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Anthony Albanese, the opposition leader, on the first day of the federal election campaign on Monday in Launceston, Australia.

item.title: Amazon vs. the Union
item.description: The company and its new union share the same problem.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Derrick Palmer, speaking during a protest outside a home belonging to Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos, in Manhattan in December 2020.

item.title: What to Know About 2022 World Cup Travel to Qatar
item.description: Tickets are on sale for the world’s most popular sporting event, but concerns over worker exploitation and laws against homosexuality have complicated the decision to attend for some fans.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Z. Klein
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Javain Brown of Jamaica and Tim Weah of the U.S. men’s national soccer team during the 2022 World Cup qualifying match in Austin, Texas, in October. The U.S. team will return to the tournament after failing to qualify in 2018.

item.title: Military Memo Adds to Possible Interstellar Meteor Mystery
item.description: The U.S. Space Command seemed to confirm a claim that a meteor from outside the solar system had entered Earth’s atmosphere, but other scientists and NASA are still not convinced.
item.dc:creator: Joey Roulette
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Office of Science and Technology Policy
item.media:description: The comet 2I/Borisov, the second known interstellar visitor to our solar system, observed by the Very Large Telescope in Chile in 2019.

item.title: Journey to Transnistria: Inside Russia’s Disinformation Bubble
item.description: We traveled inside Transnistria, a Moscow-backed breakaway state in Moldova, to find out how Russia’s disinformation campaign stretches beyond its borders.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky and Emily Rhyne
item.media:description: Emily Rhyne/The New York Times

item.title: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
item.description: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees arriving in Przemysl, Poland, from Odesa, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Obstacles to Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Moskva sank. Ukraine said it had attacked the ship with missiles. Russia said a fire had broken out.

item.title: Gina McCarthy, Top Climate Adviser, Is Said to Be Planning Departure
item.description: Ms. McCarthy was tapped by President Biden to lead an ambitious domestic climate agenda. Associates say she is frustrated by the slow pace of progress.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy, the national climate adviser, at the White House last year.

item.title: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
item.description: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Sergey Gushchin, the Russian consul general, inside the Russian Consulate in Barentsburg, Svalbard, part of a Norwegian archipelago.

item.title: Russia Hits Setbacks, as Flagship Sinks and E.U. Mulls Oil Ban
item.description: Ukraine said it hit a Russian warship in the Black Sea with its own missiles, a damaging blow to Moscow, symbolically and militarily, if its claim is confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: The missile cruiser Moskva, the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, photographed in the port of Sevastopol in 2011.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Flagship Sinks
item.description: Plus Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter and Britain’s plan to resettle asylum seekers … in Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian survivor rode a bicycle past the ruins of the village of Andriivka, west of Kyiv, on Thursday.

item.title: British Militant Convicted for Role in Deaths of Americans
item.description: The verdict capped a two-week trial that featured the testimony of former captives who detailed relentless beatings, waterboarding and killings by an Islamic State cell known as the Beatles.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: El Shafee Elsheikh, a British member of the Islamic State, was tried in Alexandria, Va., on charges of conspiracy and hostage-taking.

item.title: Russian Media Falsely Claims Ukraine Atrocity Images Are Fake
item.description: Russians are being shown some of the same distressing imagery from the war as the rest of the world, but with a big twist.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: In this picture taken by a photojournalist for The New York Times, volunteer cemetery workers loaded bodies into a truck in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: Covid Cases Strain N.H.S. Bid to Reduce Hospital Treatment Backlog, Doctors Say
item.description: The British government’s promise to shorten wait times for elective hospital procedures is threatened by high rates of positive coronavirus tests among patients and staff.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: National Health Services ambulances at a hospital in London last week.

item.title: Why Did Two Antarctic Ice Shelves Fail? Scientists Say They Now Know.
item.description: The collapse of the two ice shelves was most likely triggered by vast plumes of warm air from the Pacific, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: Even the Cactus May Not Be Safe From Climate Change
item.description: More than half of species could face greater extinction risk by midcentury, a new study found, as rising heat and dryness test the prickly plants’ limits.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: A saguaro cactus in Catalina State Park, on the edge of Tucson, Ariz.

item.title: Two U.S. Lawmakers Visit Kyiv to Show Support for Ukraine
item.description: Senator Steve Daines of Montana and Representative Victoria Spartz of Indiana, both Republicans, were invited by Ukraine’s government on short notice.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Victoria Spartz and Senator Steve Daines were shown a mass grave outside St. Andrew’s Church in Bucha during a visit to Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: On Poland-Ukraine Border, the Past Is Always Present. It’s Not Always Predictive.
item.description: For a Jewish reporter with Eastern European roots, one of the hardest challenges covering the war is reconciling the horrors of the Holocaust with the Poland and Ukraine of today.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees arriving in Przemysl, Poland, from Odesa, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: David Cronenberg and Claire Denis Will Compete at Cannes Film Festival
item.description: Organizers announced a lineup of nearly 50 movies for the event’s 2022 edition, including 18 in the running for the top honor, the Palme d’Or.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: A Crisis for Mothers
item.description: The war in Ukraine has led to familiar, but heightened, problems for women.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lubomira Pancuk, middle, with her 15-year-old daughter and infant son in Zabki, Poland.

item.title: Shanghai’s Food Crisis Prompts Beijing Residents to Stock Up
item.description: “Things that happened in Shanghai made me panic,” said Li Lilin, a real estate agent in Beijing, adding, “I’m just terrified of starving to death.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Riders loaded deliveries on their scooters in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Investigations into human rights abuses in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteer cemetery workers in Bucha, a Kyiv suburb, loading a truck on Tuesday with 65 bodies being taken for forensic investigation.

item.title: Russian Warship Is ‘Seriously Damaged’ in Black Sea
item.description: Ukraine claimed it was the same vessel that was famously and obscenely told off by Ukrainian troops in February.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Alan Yuhas

item.title: U.S. Considers Sending a High-Level Official to Kyiv
item.description: No American official has publicly visited Ukraine since Russia launched its invasion in late February.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden met with President Andrzej Duda in Warsaw last month, but it is unlikely he would go to Ukraine.

item.title: ‘Clear Patterns’ of Russian Rights Abuses Found in Ukraine, Report Says
item.description: Momentum is building to try to bring war crimes charges tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Erika Solomon and Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteer cemetery workers in Bucha, a Kyiv suburb, loading a truck on Tuesday with 65 bodies being taken for forensic investigation.

item.title: Terrorism Trial Ends With Account of Aid Worker’s Enslavement
item.description: El Shafee Elsheikh was accused of being one of four British members of the Islamic State responsible for the torture and killing of Kayla Mueller and three others.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: El Shafee Elsheikh, a British member of Islamic State, was tried in Alexandria, Va., on charges of conspiracy and hostage-taking.

item.title: Biden Announces $800 Million in Military Assistance for Ukraine
item.description: The United States will also step up intelligence sharing as Russia appears to be preparing an offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Michael D. Shear
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Shipments of Javelin antitank weapons arrived outside Kyiv, Ukraine, in February. “The American people will continue to stand with the brave Ukrainian people in their fight for freedom,” President Biden said on Wednesday.

item.title: U.K. May Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda for Processing
item.description: The details of the plan will be made public on Thursday, but local news media have reported it may include shipping immigrants to the African country.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Protesters rallied outside Parliament in January over the Nationality and Borders bill, which would lay the groundwork for processing immigrants outside Britain.

item.title: Captured Ukrainian Oligarch Was Figure in Russian Election Meddling Investigation
item.description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician close to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was also a client of Paul Manafort, the Republican political consultant and Trump campaign chairman.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk arriving for a court hearing in Kyiv in 2021 where prosecutors put him under suspicion of treason.

item.title: Le Pen Backs NATO-Russia Reconciliation and Reduced French Role in Alliance
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate for the French presidency, offered a worldview reminiscent of the Trump presidency. “No submission to an American protectorate on European soil,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen arriving to hold a news conference on diplomacy and foreign policy in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Finland and Sweden May Join NATO
item.description: Plus the world has now surpassed 500 million known Covid cases.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Paul Wennerholm/TT NEWS AGENCY, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, left, and Finnish Prime Minister Sanna Marin giving a press conference in Stockholm on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Expands Intelligence Sharing With Ukraine on Russian Forces in Donbas Region
item.description: Western officials say they expect the Kremlin to mount a major offensive in the Donbas, where Russian-backed separatists have been fighting Ukrainian forces for years.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Russian soldiers patrolling the captured town of Volnovakha, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Johnson’s Cabinet Backs Him After ‘Partygate’ Fine
item.description: The support from the British prime minister’s party means he can likely ride out the immediate storm, but his troubles are not over, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A protester in London on Wednesday called for the resignations of Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak, the chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: The Ukrainian Refugee Crisis Is a Women’s Crisis
item.description: A wave of displaced women and children into Poland is forcing the country to address its lack of protections for working women.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Skvortsova, right, with her daughter Natalia, center, and her mother, Daryna Vasylieva, with their pets at a former office building in Zabki, Poland.

item.title: Nurse Recounts Attack on Mariupol Maternity Hospital
item.description: The attack last month was among the first signs that Ukraine was facing a merciless war.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Elena Karas having her head bandaged, in a video from The Associated Press after an attack last month on a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Despite Russian Warnings, Finland and Sweden Draw Closer to NATO
item.description: The invasion of Ukraine has heightened security fears, pushing even formally nonaligned countries toward the Western alliance.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Soldiers from the Finnish Defence Forces in front of a M270 Multiple Launch Rocket System, during a joint international military exercise in Setermoen, northern Norway, in March.

item.title: South Africa Floods: Death Toll Passes 250
item.description: The devastation fueled criticism that the government should have been better prepared for the weather after intense rain in 2017 and 2019.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A bridge was destroyed after a river breached its banks in Ntuzuma, South Africa, on Wednesday.

item.title: How US and Ukrainian Groups Pierce Putin’s Propaganda Bubble
item.description: U.S.-backed news outlets and Ukrainian activists use Cold War techniques and high-tech tactics to get news about the war to Russians.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Vladimir Astapkovich/Host Photo Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is doing all he can to prevent Russians from learning the reality of Europe’s largest land war since 1945.

item.title: Israel’s Oldest Museum Takes a New Look at Israeli Art
item.description: For decades, museums presented Israeli art as a companion to the country’s history. The Tel Aviv Museum of Art breaks away from that approach — with surprising results.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The February reopening of the permanent collection of Israeli art at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art reflects a coming of age of the country’s art.

item.title: New Zealand Welcomes Vaccinated Tourists From Australia
item.description: The latest steps toward reopening are being taken in a country that has maintained some of the strictest coronavirus precautions in the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A woman welcoming her granddaughter and family from Australia at Auckland International Airport on Wednesday in New Zealand.

item.title: After Tropical Storm Megi Hits Philippines, Dozens Dead or Missing
item.description: The first such storm of the year caused widespread flooding and landslides in the central part of the country.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: The scene of a landslide that hit the village of Kantagnos, part of Baybay in Leyte Province, the Philippines, in the aftermath of Tropical Storm Megi.

item.title: Inflation’s 40-Year High
item.description: We look at why prices might ease — and why they might not.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gasoline prices have risen 48 percent since the start of the year.
